_header: Our Host gan to swear as he were wood
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the ‘Host’s Words’/‘Physician-Pardoner Link’ of the Canterbury Tales — 42 lines in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Ovre Ost gan swere as he were woodeharrow quod he bi naylis &
                    be bloode…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…I graunte I wis quod he I most me bithinkevppon some honest
                    thing while that I drynke
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And / next bigynneth Iohn Pardoner his prolog (f. 240); Here endith
                    the Pardoner his prolog… (f. 240v)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Oure oost gan swere as he were woodharow quod he be nayles & be
                    blood…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…I graunt I wys quod he but I mote thinkeVpon some honest
                    thing wile þat I drinke
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…and here / bygynnyth þe prologe of þe pardoner (f.
                        184v); here endithe þe prologe… (f. 185)

Bod414.First Lines:
[O]ure host gan swere as he were wodeharrow coth he by nailes and
                    by blood…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…I graunt y wis coth he but I mut thynkVpon sum honest thing
                    whils that I drynk

Bod686.First Lines:
Owre hoost gan to swere as he were wodeharrow quod he by nailes and
                    by blode…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…I graunte I wyis quod he but y mote þinkeVpon somme
                    honeste þing while y drynke
Bod686.Attributed Title:
…And begynneth þe mery / talkyng of þe hoost to þe
                    Phisicien and þe pardoner (f. 12)

BodHatDon1.First Lines:

                    blode…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…I graunte I wis quod he but I must thenkVpon som honest thing
                    whiles I shall drink
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
…And next biginneth / the Prolog of the Pardoner (f.
                    156v); The Pardonere (RT)

OxfTri49.Transcription:
Oure hoste gan swere as he were wodeharowe quoth he be nailis
                        and be blode
OxfTri49.Note:
At the end of Prioress’s Tale, on fol. 174, the scribe
                    writes VI.287-288 (the ‘Physician-Pardoner Link’), writes
                        ‘vacat’ next to them, and begins the Pardoner’s
                        Prologue.

                    141v)
